## Description {#details}

Class for arbitrary precision integers.

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> is a functional replacement for common case unsigned integer type like &quot;unsigned&quot;, &quot;unsigned long&quot; or &quot;uint64&#95;t&quot;, but also allows non-byte-width integer sizes and large integer value types such as 3-bits, 15-bits, or more than 64-bits of precision. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> provides a variety of arithmetic operators and methods to manipulate integer values of any bit-width. It supports both the typical integer arithmetic and comparison operations as well as bitwise manipulation.

The class has several invariants worth noting:
<ul>
<li>All bit, byte, and word positions are zero-based.</li>
<li>Once the bit width is set, it doesn&#39;t change except by the Truncate, SignExtend, or ZeroExtend operations.</li>
<li>All binary operators must be on <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> instances of the same bit width. Attempting to use these operators on instances with different bit widths will yield an assertion.</li>
<li>The value is stored canonically as an unsigned value. For operations where it makes a difference, there are both signed and unsigned variants of the operation. For example, sdiv and udiv. However, because the bit widths must be the same, operations such as Mul and Add produce the same results regardless of whether the values are interpreted as signed or not.</li>
<li>In general, the class tries to follow the style of computation that LLVM uses in its IR. This simplifies its use for LLVM.</li>
<li><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> supports zero-bit-width values, but operations that require bits are not defined on it (e.g. you cannot ask for the sign of a zero-bit integer). This means that operations like zero extension and logical shifts are defined, but sign extension and ashr is not. Zero bit values compare and hash equal to themselves, and countLeadingZeros returns 0.</li>
</ul>

Definition at line 78 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>.

Clear unused high order bits.

This method is used internally to clear the top &quot;N&quot; bits in the high order word that are not used by the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a>. This is needed after the most significant word is assigned a value to ensure that those bits are zero&#39;d out.

This is used by the toString method to divide by the radix. It simply provides a more convenient form of divide for internal use since KnuthDiv has specific constraints on its inputs. If those constraints are not met then it provides a simpler form of divide.

<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="radix">2, 8, 10, 16, or 36 Converts a string into a number. The string must be non-empty and well-formed as a number of the given base. The bit-width must be sufficient to hold the result.</ParametersListItem>

  labels = {["static"]}>
If RHS is zero LHS and REMAINDER are left unchanged, return one.

Otherwise set LHS to LHS / RHS with the fractional part discarded, set REMAINDER to the remainder, return zero. i.e.

OLD&#95;LHS = RHS &#42; LHS + REMAINDER

SCRATCH is a bignum of the same size as the operands and result for use by the routine; its contents need not be initialized and are destroyed. LHS, REMAINDER and SCRATCH must be distinct.

### tcMultiplyPart {#aaf3bfaa5ac3f017c8d3b7336d8bd4678}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>int APInt::tcMultiplyPart (<a href="#a5221357e5b7511cb0c90c94044ba35cf">WordType</a> &#42; dst, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="#a5221357e5b7511cb0c90c94044ba35cf">WordType</a> &#42; src, <a href="#a5221357e5b7511cb0c90c94044ba35cf">WordType</a> multiplier, <a href="#a5221357e5b7511cb0c90c94044ba35cf">WordType</a> carry, unsigned srcParts, unsigned dstParts, bool add)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
DST += SRC &#42; MULTIPLIER + PART if add is true DST = SRC &#42; MULTIPLIER + PART if add is false.

DST += SRC &#42; MULTIPLIER + CARRY if add is true DST = SRC &#42; MULTIPLIER + CARRY if add is false Requires 0 &lt;= DSTPARTS &lt;= SRCPARTS + 1.

Requires 0 &lt;= DSTPARTS &lt;= SRCPARTS + 1. If DST overlaps SRC they must start at the same point, i.e. DST == SRC.

If DSTPARTS == SRC&#95;PARTS + 1 no overflow occurs and zero is returned. Otherwise DST is filled with the least significant DSTPARTS parts of the result, and if all of the omitted higher parts were zero return zero, otherwise overflow occurred and return one.

If DST overlaps SRC they must start at the same point, i.e. DST == SRC. If DSTPARTS == SRCPARTS + 1 no overflow occurs and zero is returned. Otherwise DST is filled with the least significant DSTPARTS parts of the result, and if all of the omitted higher parts were zero return zero, otherwise overflow occurred and return one.

### tcSubtractPart {#a97a57add297988a66a8d6a81eff19cbb}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>APInt::WordType APInt::tcSubtractPart (<a href="#a5221357e5b7511cb0c90c94044ba35cf">WordType</a> &#42; dst, <a href="#a5221357e5b7511cb0c90c94044ba35cf">WordType</a> src, unsigned parts)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
DST -= RHS. Returns the carry flag.

This function subtracts a single &quot;word&quot; (64-bit word), src, from the multi-word integer array, dst&#91;&#93;, propagating the borrowed 1 value until no further borrowing is needed or it runs out of &quot;words&quot; in dst.

The result is 1 if &quot;borrowing&quot; exhausted the digits in dst, or 0 if dst was not exhausted. In other words, if src &gt; dst then this function returns 1, otherwise 0. 
<SectionUser title="Returns">
the borrow out of the subtraction
</SectionUser>

### ~APInt {#a280ed6ffa68d01e8757332317be2557c}

  prototype="llvm::APInt::~APInt ()"

### APInt {#a44d65323d90a63e5f572fe8f44db1154}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>llvm::APInt::APInt (unsigned numBits, uint64&#95;t val, bool isSigned=false, bool implicitTrunc=false)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Create a new <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> of numBits width, initialized as val.

If isSigned is true then val is treated as if it were a signed value (i.e. as an int64&#95;t) and the appropriate sign extension to the bit width will be done. Otherwise, no sign extension occurs (high order bits beyond the range of val are zero filled).


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="numBits">the bit width of the constructed <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a></ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="val">the initial value of the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a></ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="isSigned">how to treat signedness of val</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="implicitTrunc">allow implicit truncation of non-zero/sign bits of val beyond the range of numBits</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h/#l00111">111</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### APInt {#a4a46ba6ad1c259b7fa9bc638ebb0a2f8}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>APInt::APInt (unsigned numBits, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; uint64&#95;t &gt; bigVal)</>}>
Construct an <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> of numBits width, initialized as bigVal&#91;&#93;.

Note that bigVal.size() can be smaller or larger than the corresponding bit width but any extraneous bits will be dropped.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">

<ParametersListItem name="bigVal">a sequence of words to form the initial value of the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a></ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

### APInt {#a918deddd001f5b6d1e3439cbc5a3abab}

### APInt {#a337b62553d6b0e5ce2868e086b589a00}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>APInt::APInt (unsigned numBits, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> str, uint8&#95;t radix)</>}>
Construct an <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> from a string representation.

This constructor interprets the string <code>str</code> in the given radix. The interpretation stops when the first character that is not suitable for the radix is encountered, or the end of the string. Acceptable radix values are 2, 8, 10, 16, and 36. It is an error for the value implied by the string to require more bits than numBits.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="numBits">the bit width of the constructed <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a></ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="str">the string to be interpreted</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="radix">the radix to use for the conversion</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h/#l00170">170</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/apint-cpp/#l00116">116</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/apint-cpp">APInt.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>APInt &amp; llvm::APInt::operator= (uint64&#95;t RHS)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Assignment operator.

The RHS value is assigned to &#42;this. If the significant bits in RHS exceed the bit width, the excess bits are truncated. If the bit width is larger than 64, the value is zero filled in the unspecified high order bits.

Bitwise OR assignment operator.

Performs a bitwise OR operation on this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> and RHS. RHS is logically zero-extended or truncated to match the bit-width of the LHS.

### udivrem {#a0f0a665210e453bb16b4bf1861dbdd58}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void APInt::udivrem (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; LHS, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; RHS, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; Quotient, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; Remainder)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
Dual division/remainder interface.

Sometimes it is convenient to divide two <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> values and obtain both the quotient and remainder. This function does both operations in the same computation making it a little more efficient. The pair of input arguments may overlap with the pair of output arguments. It is safe to call udivrem(X, Y, X, Y), for example.

## Resizing Operators

### sext {#aca8fce65eb69a82aa10a635e2e79877a}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="APInt APInt::sext (unsigned width) const">
Sign extend to a new width.

This operation sign extends the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> to a new width. If the high order bit is set, the fill on the left will be done with 1 bits, otherwise zero. It is an error to specify a width that is less than the current width.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h/#l01293">1293</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/apint-cpp/#l00959">959</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/apint-cpp">APInt.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

Sign extend or truncate to width.

Make this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> have the bit width given by <code>width</code>. The value is sign extended, truncated, or left alone to make it that width.

### truncSSat {#afe04819b980f360000f64b1b5487e0a5}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="APInt APInt::truncSSat (unsigned width) const">
Truncate to new width with signed saturation.

If this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a>, treated as signed integer, can be losslessly truncated to the new bitwidth, then return truncated <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a>. Else, return either signed min value if the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> was negative, or signed max value.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h/#l01285">1285</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/apint-cpp/#l00947">947</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/apint-cpp">APInt.cpp</a>.

### getSignificantBits {#a9f78d7e839322a6bfc0c665d29052242}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="unsigned llvm::APInt::getSignificantBits () const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Get the minimum bit size for this signed <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a>.

Computes the minimum bit width for this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> while considering it to be a signed (and probably negative) value. If the value is not negative, this function returns the same value as <a href="#a3015474e70e59c0a3ed4f9f0e8644b75">getActiveBits()</a>+1. Otherwise, it returns the smallest bit width that will retain the negative value. For example, -1 can be written as 0b1 or 0xFFFFFFFFFF. 0b1 is shorter and so for -1, this function will always return 1.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h/#l01511">1511</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>.

This method attempts to return the value of this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> as a sign extended int64&#95;t. The bitwidth must be &lt;= 64 or the value must fit within an int64&#95;t. Otherwise no value is returned.

## Conversion Functions

### bitsToDouble {#acda0d1f0e4b7b739aff9601d8b4ef4e3}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="double llvm::APInt::bitsToDouble () const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Converts <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> bits to a double.

The conversion does not do a translation from integer to double, it just re-interprets the bits as a double. Note that it is valid to do this on any bit width. Exactly 64 bits will be translated.

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="APInt llvm::APInt::abs () const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Get the absolute value.

If &#42;this is &lt; 0 then return -(&#42;this), otherwise &#42;this. Note that the &quot;most negative&quot; signed number (e.g. -128 for 8 bit wide <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a>) is unchanged due to how negation works.

### getBitsSet {#a46ceedee591f92727b85641794a96061}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="static APInt llvm::APInt::getBitsSet (unsigned numBits, unsigned loBit, unsigned hiBit)"
  labels = {["inline", "static"]}>
Get a value with a block of bits set.

Constructs an <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> value that has a contiguous range of bits set. The bits from loBit (inclusive) to hiBit (exclusive) will be set. All other bits will be zero. For example, with parameters(32, 0, 16) you would get 0x0000FFFF. Please call getBitsSetWithWrap if <code>loBit</code> may be greater than <code>hiBit</code>.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="numBits">the intended bit width of the result</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="loBit">the index of the lowest bit set.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="hiBit">the index of the highest bit set.</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
An <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> value with the requested bits set.
</SectionUser>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h/#l00258">258</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getBitsSetFrom {#aeaf22e8d92fd978a5eca9ab031994399}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="static APInt llvm::APInt::getBitsSetFrom (unsigned numBits, unsigned loBit)"
  labels = {["inline", "static"]}>
Constructs an <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> value that has a contiguous range of bits set.

The bits from loBit (inclusive) to numBits (exclusive) will be set. All other bits will be zero. For example, with parameters(32, 12) you would get 0xFFFFF000.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="numBits">the intended bit width of the result</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="loBit">the index of the lowest bit to set.</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

<SectionUser title="Returns">

### getBitsSetWithWrap {#af3bee3e462a14abdf3858c354a5cd222}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="static APInt llvm::APInt::getBitsSetWithWrap (unsigned numBits, unsigned loBit, unsigned hiBit)"
  labels = {["inline", "static"]}>
Wrap version of getBitsSet.

If <code>hiBit</code> is bigger than <code>loBit</code>, this is same with getBitsSet. If <code>hiBit</code> is not bigger than <code>loBit</code>, the set bits &quot;wrap&quot;. For example, with parameters (32, 28, 4), you would get 0xF000000F. If <code>hiBit</code> is equal to <code>loBit</code>, you would get a result with all bits set.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h/#l00270">270</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/apint-h">APInt.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getSignMask {#a1e6f0d8dfed0ab631b488a3e6317718e}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="static APInt llvm::APInt::getSignMask (unsigned BitWidth)"
  labels = {["inline", "static"]}>
Get the SignMask for a specific bit width.

This is just a wrapper function of <a href="#a8f877403433892e14ff0c692cbe9efdf">getSignedMinValue()</a>, and it helps code readability when we want to get a SignMask.

</MemberDefinition>
